                        A crowd of 400 packed a private high school, cheering and jeering the candidates throughout the debate.

            By 
Kevin Robillard

11/16/15 09:34 PM EST
BATON ROUGE, La. — GOP Sen. David Vitter discussed his 2007 prostitution scandal with new openness during a rowdy and contentious final debate of the Louisiana governor's race, while also facing — and dodging — the most specific question he’s been publicly asked about his admitted misdeeds.
The 400-strong crowd packed a private high school here, with supporters of both candidates cheering, jeering, exclaiming, and applauding throughout the debate despite two warnings from the moderators to stay silent. 
Story Continued Below
Some of the loudest outbursts came after a moderator asked Vitter specifically about the phone call made famous by the Democratic state Rep. John Bel Edwards’ campaign’s “Prostitutes over Patriots” ad, questioning the specific purpose of the call. Edwards’ campaign has alleged Vitter was talking to the famous "D.C. madam" instead of voting on a Senate resolution to honor troops who had perished in combat.
Vitter didn’t answer the question, instead choosing to emphasize that the phone call took place 15 years ago and that he worked hard to earn forgiveness both from his family and from constituents in Louisiana. He blamed the media and his political opponents for keeping the issue alive.
“I’m sorry if that’s not good enough for you,” Vitter said. “It’s good enough for [Vitter’s wife] Wendy.”

White House 

            By 
Sarah Wheaton

As Vitter answered, a supporters bellowed from the auditorium: “Get over it!” Another yelled: “It’s good enough for us!”
Discussing the issue at all is a remarkable turnabout for Vitter, who hasn’t taken a question from reporters in the hallways of Senate for eight years. After a single press conference in 2007 where he admitted to a “serious sin,” the senator has steadfastly avoided the topic, even while easily winning reelection in 2010.
But in the past two debates and in recent television advertising, Vitter has been forced to bring up the scandal, casting himself as a fallen man who has found redemption with the help of his wife and family. It's a story that could resonate in a deeply religious state, but it only comes as Vitter, once considered the unstoppable favorite to be Louisiana's next governor, finds himself down by 10 percentage points or more in most public polling in the race against Edwards.
Edwards’ response was simultaneously gracious yet vicious, arguing it was appropriate to forgive Vitter but not to elect him governor.
“The simple fact of the matter is, we are all obligated as Christians to forgive,” he said. “But that doesn’t mean we have to forget.”
The Democrat later took a more direct shot: “He surrendered his law license rather than face questions, not about a sin, but about a crime.”
In a post-debate scrum, Vitter said his law license lapsed because he was no longer using it, not because he was afraid of facing questions.
“That came out of left field,” he said. “And I do mean left field.” 



            By 
Jake Sherman

In his closing statement, Vitter returned to the scandal, comparing his personal recovery from sin to a potential recovery for Louisiana as a state.
“Fifteen years ago, I faced the darkest moment of my life when I had to face my children and tell them how badly I had failed my family,” he said. “What they gave me in return was the best day in my lie when they and Wendy offered complete love and forgiveness.”
“That is the most powerful motivator I have for the rest of my life,” he continued, adding: “We’re in a low point in Louisiana. We can rise. We can go to great heights.”
Talking to reporters after the debate, Vitter said he was talking about the scandal because his failure and recovery were “the most important experience of my life.” When reporters questioned if it was shift in strategy, Vitter waved them off.
“Look, I know my answer isn’t going to satisfy y’all,” he said. “But quite frankly, you’re the gotcha media and you’re looking for headlines and you’re looking to make a name for yourselves.”
The answer also didn’t satisfy Edwards.
“I don’t know that he’s answered any of the relevant questions,” he said. “The problem is that he actually missed out on the performance of his duties. It wasn’t just something that was between him and his wife.”
The debate opened with the two candidates clashing on whether or not Louisiana should accept Syrian refugees, a topic Vitter has made the centerpiece of his campaign in recent days. Vitter accused Edwards of flip-flopping on the issue, arguing he had “four positions in forty-eight hours” and would help Obama settle refugees.



            By 
Lauren French

“I don’t know where he is,” the Republican said. “But I know we can’t trust where he’ll end up.”
Edwards accused Vitter of lying about his position, saying he proposed a moratorium on refugee resettlement and simply wanted to have a “conversation” about the topic.
“I don’t want to have a conversation,” Vitter retorted. “I want it to stop.”
The two also repeated several of their earlier clashes, with Vitter accusing Edwards of backing tax hikes and questioning the Democrat’s support for small businesses and opposition to abortion rights. Edwards responded to the latter with another character attack, noting the senator had backed a pro-abortion rights Republican, Rudy Giuliani, in the 2008 presidential race.
“You’re a hypocrite,” Edwards said.
